utterances: Thank you.
A couple of week before the election and it's very entertaining, very educational.
Even with Ken Rudin on it.
Go ahead.
Despite Ken.
I was wondering pretty much - our candidate Brad Miller, a Democrat congressman from North Carolina.
He's pretty much a strong candidate running against Vernon Robinson who - he calls himself the black Jesse Helms.
And I think there's a lot of money going into his campaign from out of state, very similar to Katherine Harris in Florida.
I was wondering what you thought about whether or not the national Republican Party is backing him financially and what you think about that particular race.
Vernon Robinson is a very, very controversial candidate.
To say he's the black Jesse Helms is really understating his appeal.
He's really come out with some extreme ads, extreme positions, and it's not a seat at all that the Republican Party thinks they can win.
So I think Brad Miller seems to be pretty safe in that district.
It's not on anybody's list.
But, you know, you mentioned Katherine Harris in Florida.
Greg Allen, our correspondent in Florida, just sent me a note that she just announced that she's selling her house in Washington to put the money towards her campaign.
She keeps talking about spending the $10 million (unintelligible) to defeat Bill Nelson in Florida.
I think the real reason she's selling her house in Washington is she's going to be soon moving back to Florida.
Greg, thanks for the call.
Thank you.
E-mail, this is from Dave in Madison, Wisconsin.

The Chicago Tribune reported on October 8th that the contest for the 8th Congressional District in northeastern Wisconsin has become the record-holder for total money spent in a midterm election - now over 3.2 million just on TV advertising.
So is there a leader in this contest?
Well, it's a Republican seat.
That's the one that Mark Green, the Republican nominee for governor, is giving up.
And John Gard is the speaker of the - I think the speaker of the assembly in Wisconsin.
And the Republicans should hold it.
But I think there's a lot of Democratic money putting into -going to that race.
And Democrats seem to be pretty hopeful that they'll take it.
My guess is that the Republicans hold on to the seat.
Let's go to Joanne(ph).
Joanne is driving to Kansas City.
Hey, how you guys doing?
Good.
Hey, I have a question.
You're talking about all of these Republicans that are in danger of losing seats.
Are there Democrats, you know, be it governors, senators, House of Representatives that are in danger of losing their seat?
Well, I love that question.
Because every time in the past we've seen big Democratic victories - 1982, 1974, 1964 - there are still Democratic incumbents who go down to defeat.
Even if it's just one or two members, Democrats go down.
It looks like right now, if the election were held right now, not one member, not one Democratic member of the Senate or the House is going to lose his or her seat.
And that includes open seats as well.

It seems like the Republican Party has once upon a time talked about going after Democratic seats, like John Barrow in Georgia or, you know, Jim Marshall of Georgia, or winning the Ted Strickland seat.
What about Debbie Stabenow, is she…
Well, again, that was a seat that the Republicans wanted from the beginning, Debbie Stabenow…
Who's the governor of Michigan?
Right.
Jennifer Granholm of Michigan.
But again, the Democrats seem to have found their footing.
And again, if there's a Democratic wave, and that seems to be the sense out there - again, there could be a last-minute Republican great Get Out the Vote effort as we saw in 2004.
But if there is a Democratic wave, and it seems to be going that way, more and more Republicans seem to be puling back and trying to defend what they have, rather in going after Democratic seats.
What about the fact too that - geez I think it's in the last two elections, the polls were really not very accurate?
Well, if we're talking about exit polls, that was certainly the case.
A lot of people thought that John Kerry had the election won because they relied on early exit polls.
But, you know, look, there's a difference between exit polls and some kind of determination of how to decide what those…
(Unintelligible) Zogby, and I'm part of this online polling network.
I think even Zogby missed it.
Well, Zogby does have the Democrats up far more than many, many analysts see it.
But again, if it's a Democratic wave, who knows what's going to happen.
Joanne, thanks very much for the call.
Thank you.
Well, look, let's not look for scandal.
We have enough scandals to worry about.
But everybody says that this is really bad news for the Democratic Party, that the only way they would win was with a centrist like Mark Warner, you know, someone who appeals to the South.
But if you look at the voters who come out to vote in the Democratic caucuses primaries, they're not moderate/conservative voters.
Look what happened in Connecticut this year.
There's so much anger about the war that it's really the left, the anti-war left that comes out.
So I'm not - we always talked about how good Mark Warner was, how smart he was, how ambitious he was and how much of an organization he had.
I'm not convinced that those - if his voters are the ones who come out and vote in the caucuses and primaries.
Political Junkie Ken Rudin is with us every Wednesday.
You can also read his column at npr.org.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
With recovery scarcely begun, the effects of Hurricane Katrina continue to add up.
The Congressional Budget Office estimated today the storm could cost the country 400,000 jobs in the coming months and slow economic growth for the rest of the year.
President Bush today asked for another $51.8 billion in hurricane aid.
That's in addition to the $10 1/2 billion Congress approved last week.
He may eventually ask for $100 billion on top of that.
And, on the individual level, federal officials announced plans today to give every Katrina survivor a $2,000 debit card.
Floodwaters continue to recede in New Orleans amid some confusion about Mayor Ray Nagin's new evacuation order.
Something like 10,000 people may still be in the city.
Police say they will not force anyone to leave, at least not as yet, and will continue to supply food and water.
National Guard commanders say they don't take orders from the mayor.
We'll get an update from New Orleans later this hour.
Our focus today is what worked and what didn't.
Those questions will be debated for months to come.
Both the White House and Congress intend to investigate the planning for and the response to Hurricane Katrina.
But we can address some preliminary questions about warning, evacuation, law enforcement and communications within and among the various emergency services.
We want to hear from you.
If you evacuated from the city of helped with the effort, what were your impressions?
If you work in city or state government, has Katrina caused you to rethink your emergency plans?
Join the conversation.
Our number here in Washington is (800) 989-8255.
That's (800) 989-TALK.
The e-mail address is totn@npr.org.
Four days before it hit the Gulf Coast, Hurricane Katrina spun across south Florida as a Category 1 hurricane; claimed nine lives there.
We start today with an explanation of how the government tracks these storms.
Richard Pass, a hurricane specialist at the National Hurricane Center in Miami, Florida, joins now by phone from his office in Miami.
Good to have you with us.
Good afternoon.
We know you're busy with Ophelia and Nate.
We appreciate your time.
And Maria.
And Maria.
Let's not forget the rest of the alphabet, yes.
Now when the Center in Florida sees a storm developing, how soon do you start issuing advisories?
Well, we issue advisories on all tropical cyclones that form in the Atlantic, Caribbean Sea, Gulf of Mexico and eastern north Pacific Ocean.
A tropical cyclone can be anything from a tropical depression with maximum sustained winds, say, of only 30 miles per hour or so, up to, of course, a hurricane, or a major hurricane.
They're all--they all get the same attention in terms of an advisory issuance every six hours.

Stronger systems, of course, as they--when they approach land, are of much more concern, and when we have a threat to land, a tropical storm or a--hurricane warnings are issued, watches or warnings are issued, and we may go to reissuance of an advisory every three hours or even every two hours with position estimates every one hour, such as we did in the case of Katrina, where we were tracking it continuously from the time it approached Florida all the way up until its landfall.
One of the things I note the Hurricane Center has been doing of late is not issuing track predictions so much as issuing a cone, a much wider area, where the storm might hit.

We are issuing--that's correct, not only a track, a specific track forecast, which, again, we don't want people to focus on, because of the uncertainties in the forecast and the size of the--and the extent of damaging winds, and Katrina was certainly an example of that.

We issue a cone, which is based on our longer-term average forecast errors that show that maybe some two-thirds to three-quarters of the time the track of the hurricane will lie somewhere within that cone and not necessarily follow the exact track because, again, there are uncertainties and there are forecast errors, particularly at two, three, four and five days in future.
Sure.
And we all know at this point that Katrina did take a job to the east at the last minute.
Well, you know what?
If you look at our track, you will see there was no job.
It turned to the north and moved due north along 89.6 degrees west that night before and into the next morning.
So it didn't strike further east than you thought?
The landfall point was probably within about 30 miles of the location, give or take.
And given--one of the things...
This is--excuse me.
Certainly.
That was within, say, 24 hours of landfall.
Obviously, further out than the track--there were differences, but, you know, I'm talking about from the time when it was beginning to approach the coast by--you know, on Sunday afternoon.
